intro: Rhynchosinapis cheiranthos subsp. cheiranthiflora, commonly known as the cheiranthiflorous rhynchosinapis, is a flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its compact growth habit and distinctive floral morphology, with small, clustered flowers that are typically white or pale yellow. The plant produces siliques, which are elongated, dry fruits that contain numerous small seeds. It is native to specific regions in southern Africa, where it thrives in rocky or sandy soils. Due to its limited distribution and unique botanical features, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
